misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that all variables used throughout the program—including loop counters—must be declared and initialized at the beginning of the method. They also appear to believe that pattern-based problems require a standard triplet of variables (a, b, and c) regardless of whether the specific logic requires two or three dimensions.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student is unaware of block-level scope, which allows variables to be declared within 'for' loop headers. They also show a misunderstanding of variable necessity, as evidenced by initializing 'c' even though it is not utilized in the algorithm, and they are re-initializing 'a' and 'b' immediately after their first declaration.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The presence of unused variables and redundant initialization of loop counters outside of the loop scope.
